resources.string:
•The Villa features recurring shapes, such as the diamond and the eight-pointed star.

 •The ceiling beams are original and made of cypress. The construction materials were all bought locally.

 •The entire Villa, plus 4 acres of land, was bought by the Quincy Park District in 1955, which used it as a community center for neighborhood children for several years.

 •Friends of the Castle began restoration of the entire exterior and interior of the Villa Kathrine in 1978 and completed it in 1998.

•The Villa was built in 1900 by Quincy native, William "George" Metz, for $7,000.

 •The Courtyard is a gallery supported by Byzantine-styled arches. The balcony rests on eight Islamic Pillars, making The Villa is the only Islamic-influenced architecture in Quincy.

 •In the center is a reflecting pool. The whole room is designed to mimic a Mid-Eastern pattern.

•Lavish parties were often held at the Villa, often with people sitting around the reflecting pool.

 •The China cabinet and the buffet are original. The nickel-plated brass on the cabinet is also original.

 •The back porch and pantry were built to form a windbreak, and to provide a service entrance.

•Also called the "Smoking Room", this room features a particularly beautiful view of the Mississippi River.

 •Under the window there used to be an alabaster fireplace fa√ßade.

 •Architect George Behrensmeyer drew the blueprint for the Villa.

•The Master Bedroom is the largest room on the second floor; its windows have views to the North and East.

 •The Villa's walls are twelve to eighteen inches thick brick, covered by one half to one inch think plaster.

 •There is a fireplace or wood-burning stove in every (original) room. Also, the rooms all have doors that open into the Courtyard.

 •William "George" Metz was said to have a 212 pound Mastiff dog named "Bingo"."
